post.author: urbnoracle
post.post_title: Periodontal Disease Risk: Treatments for Pockets?
post.post_content:
Hello, at a recent dentist visit I was informed I had early stage periodontal disease—the stage where your teeth look perfectly normal but your gums are a bit inflamed and you bleed a bit when you floss or brush. It doesn't bother me much at present. I was recommended to get a treatment with an antibiotic coating called Arestin but insurance doesn't cover it and it's $75 per pocket. I have a total of 7 pockets and was not willing to pay this much at the time. My dentist advised we follow up during my next cleaning in 6 months to assess the progression of my pockets/periodontal disease risk.

I'm wondering whether there are alternatives to Arestin that doctors recommend? I'm also wondering: Is it necessary to get such a treatment or can I just continue to brush and floss regularly (at present I brush after practically every meal but always after breakfast and dinner and I floss after eating anything)? Are there less expensive ways to reduce risk or treat pockets?

I'm going to also call my insurance company to see if alternative treatments might be approved (alternative antibiotic treatments, I mean...not necessarily CAM).

Any insight or input or advice would be greatly appreciated. Thank you so much in advance for reading and responding.

post.author: dorlow
post.post_title: So, I'm 40 and it looks like I'm getting braces AGAIN!
post.post_content:
So, when I was a kid, I had braces. My teeth were really messed up. The orthodontist fixed all my visible teeth, so when I smile, my teeth look good. But he didnt fix my back teeth. My back teeth on both sides curve in a lot to where my tongue barely has any space. Its always bothered me. A few days ago, I had a problem with the perminant retainer that I had put in when I was 18. While I was at the orthodontist ( a different ortho.. completely different state and I'm pretty sure my old ortho is no longer practicing), I asked him about how my back teeth curve in so much. Over the last 20 years. I've asked other orthodontist about it a few times and gotten different answers how it could be fixed. This orthodontist says he can fix it with braces. Now that I'm an adult, insurance wont cover it. Its going to be $6,000 to fix it. I keep thinking $6,000 to fix something that has bothered me my whole life isnt a big deal.

I guess what I'm wondering is how is it going to change my face profile if it works? My teeth in the back severely curve in to where my tongue has no room. I constantly bite my tongue eating. I don't chew gum for this reason. I'm hoping if my jaw is wider, my to tongue would have more room to move. I also have sleep apnea. I use a cpap to fix it, but maybe fixing my back teeth will give my tongue more room and relieve some of my sleep apnea issues.

But I guess I'm now wondering how my face is going to change. My jaw currently curves in on my back teeth then out (the opposite of what it's supposed to do.) If they fix it to have my jaw curve out, how will it change my face profile? I guess I'm self conscience of my underbite. My chin is too far back. As my teeth move straight, my jaw would move forward. But as they move my jaw so its curved out, maybe my chin will be in further than it is now.

Also, does anyone know how my ortho is going to pull the teeth out? Dont understand how braces on my teeth are going to force my teeth and jaw to widen. Unless I'll have to wear head gear at night and that will pull my teeth out. I'll have to ask my ortho next time I see him. Maybe someone here knows.

responses.author: dorlow
responses.resp_title: RE: So, I'm 40 and it looks like I'm getting braces AGAIN!
responses.resp_content: Also, another problem I have is I have TMJ. I need to constantly clench my teeth. If I relax my jaw for too long (like when I go to the dentist for a cleaning), by the end of the cleaning, my teeth don't line up. I need to then clench my jaw for a while to get my teeth to move back in place. I don't know if the braces widening my jaw will fix that too.

responses.resp_title: RE: My teeth feel fine. Do I still need to see a dentist?
responses.resp_content: Hey, friend, you should definitely go to the dentist. To be honest, it's a necessary procedure to go to the dentist twice a year at least! By the way, I would like to share my story (I tell you it due to the fact that I don't want that people repeat my mistakes). I brushed my teeth every day, I didn't have any toothache and I thought everything was fine, however, once my mom took me to the dentist and I was shocked by the diagnosis. Caries of the lower jaw, 2 holes and incorrectly grown tooth... And you know what? I thought that the treatment of all these problems will take at least six months, but the doctor in the dental clinic I visited cured my teeth in about a week. Yes, I visited this clinic almost every day to cure my teeth, but the treatment was painless, and it was due to the fact that as it turned out that this clinic has highly qualified dentists...

responses.author: rosiecont
responses.resp_title: RE: My teeth feel fine. Do I still need to see a dentist?
responses.resp_content: Oral health is attracting more and more people's attention. Now the oral periodontal disease rate is growing at a rate of 40% every year! And the mouth is also the most prone to bacteria, it is very necessary to do oral examinations on a regular basis.

responses.author: mrssandman
responses.resp_title: RE: My teeth feel fine. Do I still need to see a dentist?
responses.resp_content: You should do regular check ups all the time. I honestly feel like it will be better for you if you do regular check ins at the dentist, just because you don't always feel the cavity in the early stages of it's formation. I have been like you in the past. I would skip my appointments just because I thought it was fine. Recently though I moved to Miami and got a new dentist. He was not really happy with me for not keeping up my regular appointments. I had a few cavities that I could have avoided if I was more consistent. I've been more disciplined since I came here. The staff at this clinic is very nice and the dentist is a great professional. If you need a new dentist in the Miami area you should definitely come for a test appointment. (Here is their website: https://www.artisticsmilesmiamidentist.com/cosmetic-dentistry/)

post.author: psychdan123
post.post_title: Pulsating “bump” below skin on Facial Artery on cheek about an inch from my mouth
post.post_content: So I have noticed a bump below the skin for about a year now. It is soft to the touch and not discolored. I can only see it in certain lighting but recently within the past month I have noticed it is pulsing with my heartbeat. I have felt my facial artery and followed it from the mandible and it feels larger on my left than on my right. I have gone to the dermatologist and they said they had never seen anything like that before. I then went to an oral surgeon who suggested I go and get an angiogram CT for the possibility it is a facial AVM. I have been worried about that possibility non stop and I wanted to post this because I have seen other people online post about similar pulsating bumps under the skin about the size of a pea near their mouths and I wanted to start this new thread because all the old ones were closed and didn’t allow me to post or comment. I was wondering if anyone has had a similar situation and if it was an AVM or if it was just that their facial artery was large and close to the surface in a particular area. I am a male and 21 years old so for it to be a facial AVM I feel that I would be diagnosed pretty late considering most AVM’s are formed around birth. I am looking to see if anyone could offer another possible theory on what it is and/or find people with the same condition so I can let you know what the results of my CT angiogram says because no one seems to know what is going on with this pulsing in my face. I am getting the CT next Friday so I will come back and post my results but in the meantime if anyone thinks they might have an alternate hypothesis please let me know and if you have this same issue, what did you find out.

responses.author: Anonymous
responses.resp_title: RE: Pulsating “bump” below skin on Facial Artery on cheek about an inch from my mouth
responses.resp_content: Hey, what happened? I’m 21 and have started to feel this bump too

responses.author: psychdan123
responses.resp_title: Ok so I went to a vein specialist who looked at it with an ultrasound. He said the blood flow in it was completely normal and it didn’t look like an AVM. He said it looked like my facial artery came up closer to the surface and made a loop. He said that’s why I could see the pulse under the skin. Apparently it’s not that uncommon but for someone like me without a lot of fat on my face to disguise it I could see it. I looked up online about facial artery ligation and there are some plastic surgeons who have done things that can reduce how much you can see it. Don’t freak out like I did thinking I had an AVM. They’re super rare I’d suggest going to a vein specialist and having them do an ultrasound. Let me know if you need anything else. I was super frustrated when I was looking up things about this because there’s nothing out there.

responses.author: weldental
responses.resp_title: RE: Bad Breath
responses.resp_content:
Often bad breath is caused by the bacteria that creates plaque. This bacteria thrives on sugar, which is in almost everything we eat. Xylitol is a safe natural sweetener that is almost identical to sugar, except this harmful bacteria can't metabolize it and starves. Minimize this bacteria and your bad breath will no longer be a problem.

Use a Xylitol based toothpaste, Xylitol water flosser, Xylitol mints and/or Xylitol gum.

post.post_title: How do I know if my Dentist is qualified
post.post_content: I'm nervous about going to my Dentist as it is. My question is my dentist wants to remove two badly broken teeth to the point where there is not much there. Do I need to see a oral surgeon or is a basic DDS Periodontics Dentist qualified? Thank you for your input

responses.author: Anonymous
responses.resp_title: RE: How do I know if my Dentist is qualified
responses.resp_content:
Find the right dentist can be difficult. Once you go with a dentist, you're taking a leap of faith and hoping that he can get the job done right.

The best way to assess the skill of a dentist is to see if he has additional board certifications and stays up to date with continuous training and education.

You may also want to ask him for pictures of the previous work he's performed. Reviews can also help, but they are getting harder and harder to trust these days.

I found this info directly off this site: https://www.mydentistvienna.com/our-services/cosmetic-dental-services/cosmetic-dentistry/

Hope this helps!

responses.author: jvpdent
responses.resp_title: RE: Bleeding gums
responses.resp_content: Great question! First of all, are you using a manual soft toothbrush or an electric one? Are you flossing daily? When was the last time you have seen a dentist? We brush two minutes, two times a day, floss (or use Waterpik) daily, and use an alcohol-free mouthwash twice daily after brushing to prevent bacterial plaque buildup. By keeping bacterial levels low, our gums are healthier and happier, therefore less bleeding. If you are having darker bleeding, this could mean several things: 1) overdue for a dental hygiene appt; 2) suffering from a medical issue like Diabetes. Diabetics are slow wound healers, and suffer from weaker gums; 3) if you are a woman and pregnant, you may be experiencing pregnancy gingivitis, quite common, especially for first time mommies. Any time we suffer from a cold/sinus infection, our mouths suffer as well since the immune system cannot keep the mouth healthy too. If this persists longer than a week I would make an appt with a dentist. Good luck!

Tips

post.author: babubhayya
post.post_content: 1 of my fronth tooth is broken, my doctor suggested me to put Zirconia crown. But he is saying he can not guarantee the color that matches with existing tooth. So, he suggested me to put 2 crowns for front 2 teeth for aesthetic purpose. I just want to know does the color really do not match with other teeth? Please suggest

responses.author: Anonymous
responses.resp_title: RE: 1 of the front tooth broken
responses.resp_content:
Most skilled dentists can color match your teeth use a shade palette. I don't know why your dentist recommends to do both teeth as that sounds completely unnecessary. One thing to note is that if you are going to do a crown procedure, you should first whiten your teeth to look as bright as possible. Your new zirconia crown will be bleach resistant and stain resistant.

Here is a good article explaining why: https://www.mydentistvienna.com/our-services/cosmetic-dental-services/dental-crowns-and-dental-bridges/ . If you don't whiten your teeth first and choose to do it later, your crown will stay the same shade and it won't look good.

Good luck

post.author: laclair1
post.post_title: Tooth Abscess...Treatment working or not working?
post.post_content:
Yesterday I went to the dentist due to a very (very) painful tooth that would not quit throbbing. I was diagnosed with a tooth abscess. After taking two doses of antibiotics (I am taking 500mg of penicillin every 6 hours - 3 doses, thus far), the lump at the back of my tooth had reduced a bit, the throbbing was tolerable, and I had hoped the medication was working. Placebo effect is possible, too, of course.

This morning, however, I woke up to find no lump directly above the tooth, but pressure and swelling just below the apple of my cheek. I've never had an abscessed tooth like this before. Is it possible the infection has "spread" or is this just a normal progression and sign the antibiotics are fighting whatever infection was already in that area?

responses.author: Anonymous
responses.resp_title: RE: Tooth Abscess...Treatment working or not working?
responses.resp_content:
First up, I feel your pain. About 4 years back I had an abcessed tooth, too. (took me 2 months before I realized it wasn't a wisdom tooth coming it. It was a back tooth with a honkin' big cavity in it and, because of that, an infection, too. yay me.)

Second, that's surprisingly fast for the lump above your tooth to be gone. I can't speak for everyone, but I thought it took a bit more time before the actual lump of infection would get removed because of the penicillin.

Either way, I figure that if the pain has lessened, that's a good sign. If you were taking the penicillin (I got omoxicillin... sp? amoxicillin?) and the pain got spiked up after taking it, then, if I were in your shoes, I'd be seriously worried.

(mind you, I'm not a doctor or medical professional by any means. Just someone who's had the unfortunate hand of being stuck with an infection due to a tooth twice already in her life.)
My thoughts on this?
Give it, at least, 5 days.
Keep taking the penicillin to fight off that infection. (well, keep doing that regardless. Infections of any kind are nothing to take lightly since they *can* kill if left to get bad enough.)
Keep monitoring and see how that area of your mouth, and your afflicted tooth, are doing. (This is simply a good rule of thumb in general, if you ask me.)
If things keep improving, then good. If you suddenly start feeling sick, feeling worse than you were before you started the penicillin, or are in oodles more pain, get your butt to a hospital as fast as humanly possible.

And, you know, if your curiousity gets the better of you, call up your dentist and ask him / her about this. With all of their years of training and education, they're bound to know all about this stuff, and it never hurts to ask.

responses.author: jdode4
responses.resp_title: RE: Frontal lobe headache and tingling teeth
responses.resp_content:
For the past year, I've had tingling and pressure in the upper left molar area. Two rearmost molars were extracted years ago, but the remaining two seemed to be experiencing pressure and mild tingling. Dental x-rays show the sinuses coming down around the two remaining teeth roots. The teeth tested dead during a cold test. As a matter of fact, all of the upper teeth tested negative to the cold test. That is highly unusual, but may be due to pressing the teeth together, because of the feeling of pressure. Excessive grinding can cause teeth to die.

Eventually, the dead molars in the area of pressure were extracted. I still have the feeling of pressure, but not as much as before the teeth were extracted. I have been waiting to have an upper partial plate made. When the last of the molars were extracted a large amount of the bony matter that holds teeth in place, in the gums, was extracted with the tooth. I have read that if not enough bony matter is in the gums, it allows the sinuses to come down around the tooth roots and that causes a sense of pressure or tingling.

Tomorrow, I'm having a CAT scan of the sinuses to see if there is any problem. I don't have any headaches, just the pressure and slight tingling. I do have active sinuses in the mornings with a lot of nose blowing. After a couple of hours, no more runny nose.

I have read of a similar situation with 4-5 other posters on this site. One was helped by Sudafed. Another developed the problem when taking Sudafed. Another was helped by pinching the bone of her nose and pushing it to the other side. One was helped by using a Neti Pot. It does seem to be sinus related. One person said that a friend, who was a diver, said it sounded exactly like 'pneumatized sinus'.

I found this: Extensive maxillary sinus pneumatization (EMSP) was defined as one in which the largest horizontal and/or vertical dimension of the maxillary sinus equalled or exceeded 90% of the corresponding diameter of the orbit.

Hopefully, my upcoming CAT will reveal something.

responses.author: Anonymous
responses.resp_title: RE: Some of a tooth randomly missing, I think lol
responses.resp_content: I wouldn't worry about having aspirated the fragment; probably swallowed it. What you should be concerned about is a possible problem with the tooth that allowed that molar to fracture. I'd get a dental checkup (general, annual exam) and find out if there is something else besides the chip going on with that tooth. Cavity? Large existing filling (with resultant weak portions of tooth)? The cheek side of that last tooth is often not brushed very well and is, therefore, prone to getting decay, weakening the parts that are not decayed which are then easily broken. BTW, if this is a wisdom tooth, you may just want to have it removed.

responses.resp_content:
Reply
Anonymous
over 2 years ago
Well, if you have a cavity (decay), then it's only a matter of time before it becomes deep enough to cause discomfort, and eventually, constant pain (i.e., the nerve is extremely inflamed or infected); if that pain keeps you from sleeping, then it's shot. In this case, root canal treatment (endodontic treatment) is the ideal treatment, mainly because you get to keep the tooth. However, in addition to that expense, you must restore the tooth, which involves a large filling, and in most cases is ideally followed by placing a crown on the tooth. Yes, it's all very expensive (esp. without dental insurance), probably in excess of $2000 total.

OK, you always have the option of having it pulled (extracted), even if it could be saved. The choice is yours. That might cost you a couple of hundred dollars; I don't know. If the tooth you describe is actually the last one in the back, after a month or two you'll adapt to its loss (and it should have healed by then), and it won't really be a big deal; you won't starve.

Some communities and/or counties have free dental services, services provided by volunteer dental personnel. You should investigate. If you live near a dental school, you can check there, although there usually are fees for treatment, at a reduced rate.

Anyway, check these suggestions out. If your dental problem evolves to the point of serve, constant pain, your choices will end up being limited without having taken the time to thoroughly investigate your options.

responses.resp_title: There are a couple of reasons your tooth "feels" lose. 1.) If you grind or clinch your teeth this can loosen your teeth. This is usually done while sleeping.

post.author: Anonymous
post.post_title: Labor Day weekend, abscess tooth, what to do in the meantime?
post.post_content:
It started on Thursday, when I took a nap and woke up with a mild, general tooth pain in a lateral incisor, and had slightly affected my central incisor. I thought I had been grinding my teeth in my sleep, as I often do, so I swished around warm salt water, took a Tylenol, and called it a day.

Friday, it was more prominent but not painful or obstructive. I did notice a numbness in my upper lip, and it was a tad swollen.I went out and bought Sensodyne for my tooth pain, thinking that it was just sensitive from grinding it in my sleep the previous day. It didn't start to get my attention until 6 in the evening, after my dentist's hours had closed. I took more Tylenol, applied some Orajel, and called it a day.

Saturday morning, I wake up early (5:30am) and my entire left cheek is swollen. I did some search on the internet, and I'm pretty sure it's an infection due to an abscessed tooth. I called my dentist, and with no surprise, they are closed, as it's Labor Day weekend. I found out I can't get an appointment until TUESDAY.

In the meantime, I am placing warm salt water in the area of my incisors every hour, switching between two ice packs every 15 minutes, eating soft foods, and taking amoxicillin. I had just taken my second dose of it today, and plan to take my last one for the day in about 8 hours. I am hoping that the amoxicillin and warm salt water will help with keeping the infection under control. I hope I am doing enough until Tuesday.

With that said, I need your help. Is there anything else I can do in the meantime? I'm thinking more, over-the-counter things, as I feel already feel like a liability, being a dependent on my parents, so urgent care isn't a priority to me unless it's absolutely necessary. Please let me know if I'm doing enough!

Thanks in advanced!

post.author: moonbeam04
post.post_title: Am I being reasonable in deciding to have an extraction instead of root canal?
post.post_content:
My dentist told me I need a root canal, since my wisdom tooth grew into one of my teeth. After being told this I did some research on root canals. Based on this information, I think it would be reasonable for me to opt for an extraction instead of a root canal. Using only American Endodontics Association, American Dental Association studies, and other pubmed studies, I learned the following:

-Root canal teeth, even when done correctly, have higher endotoxin levels than teeth with vital pulps. The mean value of endotoxin is over 28 times greater in root canal teeth, according to a study published in the Journal of Endodontics.
-Root canal teeth are much more likely (about 40% more likely) to be effected by apical periodontitis, according to studies done by the American Endodontics Association and American Dental Association.
-Apical periodontitis is strongly associated with brain aneurisms and heart disease, according to pubmed.
-Endotoxins are associated with depression symptoms, according to pubmed. Specifically, the study linked root canal endotoxins to depression: https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pubmed/28455694
-Root canal procedures are associated with heart disease. People who have a history of root canal procedures are 1.62 times more likely to suffer from heart disease, according to this study: https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC2735042/
There are other studies linking root canal procedures with heart disease as well. Also consider that some of those people may have had their root canal teeth removed early on, and this would make those numbers even higher if they had considered this in their data.

I also have reason to believe that I have a low level infection that has been going on for a while, or possibly endotoxins interfering with my health. I think this because I've had horrible brain fog and low energy levels for 2 years, but when my dentist put me on a week of penicillin for my wisdom tooth removal, I felt much, much better. Like a fog had lifted for the first time in a while. I also had tachycardia and arrhythmia that went on for 6 months, then mysteriously went away.

I've been unemployed for a long time because of my health. I used to be a productive, busy student with 2 jobs and an active social life before this. I think it is more likely my health will improve in the long run if I have my tooth extracted instead of getting a root canal. I want to know if I'm being reasonable. Most of the dentists I have seen dismiss all that I have to say and all my reasons, and act like they're stupid reasons, they seem to think it's ok to ignore the research. I think root canals are something only healthy people should do, because they can take a toll on your body.

Also, another dentist started a root canal on that tooth against my wishes, so the tooth is open. I had to take penicillin because my oral surgeon noticed a low level infection had started after the other dentist did that.

I wanted to ask this question because I am going to lose my first (non-wisdom) tooth. I know this could possibly effect the alignment of my jaw unless I decide to get an implant, so it's a big decision.

responses.author: otter100
responses.resp_title: RE: Am I being reasonable in deciding to have an extraction instead of root canal?
responses.resp_content: Hey. I'm having a terrible time with a root canal I had done this past week. What did you decide? And how are you doibg?

responses.author: moonbeam04
responses.resp_title: I got it extracted, and I am so glad I did! Soon after it was removed I had this immense sense of calm and well being that I hadn't had for a long time. I think the infected tooth was rough on my body. It's been a while since I had it done (at an oral surgeon, not a regular dentist) and I haven't had any issues. What kind of symptoms are you having? And did you go to an endodontist, instead of just a regular dentist? (this is important to avoid complications afterwards). You may have to get the root canal re-done, an apicoectomy, or have it extracted. I suggest you look up online reviews of the endodontist before you choose one.
responses.resp_content:
I did a lot of research. What I learned is that no seal is perfect, they all will leak eventually, and it is impossible to clean out all the infected dentin because there are millions of microtubules in the tooth. Even endodontists who want to sell more root canals will agree with those two facts. This means there will be small amounts of infection leaking into your body. Someone who is healthy can probably easily deal with this no problem, but if you are sensitive and/or having lots of health issues that could have something to do with an infection in your body, I think it's wise to consider getting it extracted instead. If you want to keep your tooth, a very good endodontist could probably give you a good chance of a successful procedure with no complications afterwards.

I do kind of wonder if a root canal would have helped me with all the health issues and let me keep the tooth, but it seemed like such an expensive gamble, so I took the option that seemed best for my overall health.

responses.author: Anonymous
responses.resp_title: RE: Tooth #2 Crown vs Extraction
responses.resp_content: I know that there's mixed views on this. I have a crown on one of my bottom teeth but opted to just get my top back tooth extracted because the cost was much less and money was really tight at the time. As it was explained to my by my dentist, while a crown is preferred it wasn't 100% necessary in my case. There wasn't really a question about getting a crown on the bottom because those teeth take the most biting force so going without down there wasn't an option for me. responses.author: Anonymous
responses.resp_title: RE: TMJ? / Back & Arm pain
responses.resp_content:
Sorry to hear that you are suffering from this condition. So based on the information provided by you, I need few more information related to your medical history, personal details such as gender, age. 2 xrays - 1) Water's view to rule out sinus issue 2) TMJ - MRI to rule out disk and TMJ CT SCAN - to rule out any TMJ abnormality.

Also Bite analysis to evaluate occlusion is important factor in the diagnosis.
Basicaly it's impossible to suggest anything here, please visit Oral and Maxillofacial surgeon or General Dentist.

post.author: naathim
post.post_title: Recurrent infections following wisdom tooth extraction
post.post_content:
I had my lower wisdom teeth surgically extracted three months ago. I was placed on two courses of post-op antibiotics (augmentin 1 week post op and clindamycin about 1 mo. post op) and I thought all was well. Approximately two weeks ago, I started having pain and swelling on the right side. Oral surgeon went in and debrided it. No direct cause of infection like a sliver of bone or food particle, just some pus. Started another round of clindamycin and peridex. About 10 days through this course I started having diffuse pain on my left side. The pain is mostly concentrated in the area where I had my extraction, sometimes it feels sore on the upper jaw area on that left side, sinus pain, sometimes I'll get a sharp pain up towards my ear, and sometimes I'll have some numbness/tingling towards my chin. About the only thing that takes it away is 600mg of ibuprofen about every 10 or so hours. I called my surgeons office and I'm going to see him again in 2 days for my follow-up for the right and probably a debridement on the left side as well.

I'm just very scared. The symptoms on this left side are worse than they were on the right and I'm already on a good antibiotic. I'm worried that I'm going to end up with a systemic infection or osteomyelitis.

I've taken all my antibiotics religiously, I even wake up in the middle of the night to take the clindamycin q6. 28 year old, no major health issues. I know being older increases chances of complications, but I'm just surprised I'm having this much trouble healing.

Thank you for reading my vent session. If anyone wants to tell me I'm not going to die now, I'd appreciate it.

responses.author: WebMD Addie
responses.resp_title: RE: Recurrent infections following wisdom tooth extraction
responses.resp_content: I am so sorry that you are going through this. I know how awful mouth pain can be! How did your appointment with your surgeon go? I hope that you are on the mend!

post.author: deputyscraps
post.post_content:
I recently went to a dermatologist to have a mucocele removed, this was in September 2016. They basically used a scalpel and sliced horizontally, cutting it out entirely and then cauterizing the wound. This left a crater-like hole in my lower lip. It has healed some since then, but there is still a very noticeable crater with scar tissue.

I have been reading since then that in most cases the doctor makes a small incision, removes the mucocele, and then stitches it back up. My experience seemed much more invasive than that. I think they were rushing and wanted me out of their office as quickly as possible.

A couple questions:

A. What is the likelihood of this 'crater' healing completely? How much time should it take? It's been ~5 months.

B. If it doesn't heal, is this grounds for a lawsuit? I would rather not but if this guy permanently disfigured my lip needlessly then I would feel compelled to.

responses.author: WebMD Addie
responses.resp_title: RE: Mucocele Removal Problem
responses.resp_content:
I am unsure about the time it takes to fully heal, or if you will be left with a scar. That may be something to discuss with your doctor.

This article has some information about mucocele removal and says that one treatment option is where: "The dentist or doctor may use a scalpel or laser to remove the salivary gland." This sounds similar to the procedure you describe. You can read more here: http://wb.md/2l0RLlC

responses.resp_title: RE: Dental Question
responses.resp_content: if you had it pulled, yes your other teeth would probably move. Best thing to do is have a dental implant or ask your dentist about options for socket preservation. This means that there will be enough bone mass later for when you decide or are ready to do the implant. The present danger is risk of root canal infection or abcess. I would see a dentist, get x rays to make sure that there is no infection and get the tooth removed

responses.author: noramae0488
responses.resp_title: RE: Dental Implants
responses.resp_content: My sister had this done when she was in middle school. When she lost her baby teeth she had some adult teeth that just never formed. I think she had a total of 6 implants put in. Her dentist did it in 3 procedures - 2 to put in the posts and anchors and then 1 to actually put on the tooth she has now. I remember she was really nervous to have it done and the first surgery was painful for her. Now you would never be able to tell that they aren't her natural teeth and she never seems to have any problems eating with them. I don't remember her having temporary teeth while healing from the first surgeries, but if she did I guess they just never caused problems. I'm pretty sure she would tell you that she wouldn't hesitate to do it again. If you don't feel right about what your dentist is suggesting, I don't think it hurts to get another opinion.

responses.author: natedw

responses.resp_content:
My father and a husband of my sister have done it. Both have been happy with treatment and outcome. They have never complained complained of pain, bleeding or discomfort. You might want to read more reviews, dentalimplantsfriends com is a great source.

post.post_content: I’m a 51-year old man, in excellent health, take no medications, and feel great; except that in June of 2016 (approximately six months ago) I cracked a molar while biting down on a rock-like baked seed in a bagel, which hurt like hell, but I ignored it and the pain diminished, and half of the molar fell off (down to the exposed root) a few weeks later. I don’t believe it ever got infected: I never had any symptoms of an infection. Since I cracked the molar, I’ve been brushing the cracked molar very thoroughly, including within the recessed area of the fissure down to the exposed root. Relatively recently, approximately 6 weeks ago, I began experiencing a bitter taste in my mouth, which is overpowering when drinking bitter (or astringent) liquids, especially coffee and red wine. I haven’t changed my diet or eating habits for many years, and I’ve been taking the same type of typical once-daily multivitamins for many years. This bitter taste finally motivated me to go to the dentist two weeks ago, also because I have some receding gums with exposed roots (bot NOT gingivitis or periodontitis), and figured it was time to address my gums also. My dentist found NO signs of an infection anywhere in my mouth, but advised that my cracked molar should be extracted (scheduled for eleven days from now), and also that my teeth with the most severely receded gums should be bonded/filled (one was bonded/filled a week ago); and my dentist also observed that my teeth were very clean (probably due to my overly thorough brushing). Over my lifetime, I’ve had many colds, and a few flus and sinus infections, but I’ve NEVER experience this bitter taste in my mouth! What could be causing this?

post.post_title: Help! Burning feeling in mouth for about a year
post.post_content: For close to a year now I've had a kind of burning sensation on my tongue. It gets worse if I eat something spicy or minty, but it is pretty much there all the time. Sometimes I think that it has gone away but nope. When I look at my tongue in the mirror it's patchy almost like geographic tongue which is what my dentist originally thought I had. It doesn't bother me to the point that I want to pay for an extra doctor visit, I'd just like to know if anyone else has had this burning feeling and what it turned out to be.

responses.author: WebMD Addie
responses.resp_title: RE: Help! Burning feeling in mouth for about a year
responses.resp_content:
Thank you for posting! The best thing that you can do is to see your doctor or dentist for an evaluation. Do you have any regularly scheduled exams or dental cleanings that you could bring this question up at? A medical professional will be best able to determine what is causing this burning sensation and how to help you.

In the meantime, you may want to take a look at this article about burning mouth syndrome (the name for burning pain in your mouth that has no known cause): http://wb.md/2dGg0rK If the symptoms listed are similar to what you are experiencing, you may wish to bring this up with your doctor.

Please let us know how you're doing and if you find any answers!

post.author: sabrina24
post.post_content:
For quite a few years sometimes my jaw would lock when I tried to open it and I'd have to close it and reopen it but now it just pops sometimes when I open my mouth. Recently I've noticed a crackling in my ear that ONLY happens when I open my jaw but it's kind of turned into a really light pop. By light I mean it's hard to hear unless the room is silent. But I've also noticed that when my jaw pops it's at the bottom bend of the jaw below my ear. And I'm not having any pains or soreness (unless I make my jaw pop multiple times). I've not had any injuries or surgeries. But on the bottom row of my teeth, the second to last tooth on both sides is missing (were removed due to cavities).
Because I don't have any pain or soreness and the popping happens at the bottom of my jaw, I don't think it's muscle related so what could it be? Should I see a doctor even though it's not bothering me?

responses.author: WebMD Addie
responses.resp_title: RE: Jaw popping and crackling
responses.resp_content:
Hi sabrina24 This may be a good thing to discuss with your doctor or your dentist at your next regularly scheduled appointment.

This article says that "problems with your jaw and the muscles in your face that control it are known as temporomandibular disorders (TMD)," and that common symptoms can include "clicking, popping, or grating sounds in the jaw joint when you open or close your mouth or chew. This may or may not be painful." You can read more to see if this sounds like what you are experiencing here: http://wb.md/2doZSpP

It may be worth discussing if this is what is possibly causing the symptoms you describe, or if they are a result of something else with a medical professional.

Hope you'll check back in and let us know how you're doing!

post.author: thewalkingeagle
post.post_content: Been having some weird symptoms. Pink eye, thrush, yeast infections and just feel overall sick. Or at least I think it's thrush. Thick layering on my tongue. Don't know what to do to get rid of it. This and my pink eye keep reoccurring. Any ideas? It's a nightmare!

responses.author: WebMD Addie
responses.resp_title: RE: Possible thrush
responses.resp_content:
Hi thewalkingeagle I'm sorry that you are dealing with all of these symptoms. Have you had a chance to see your doctor? He/She is best able to determine why the thrush and pink eye keep occurring and provide you with possible treatment options.

In the meantime, here is some information on thrush that you may find helpful to compare to what you are experiencing: http://wb.md/2cSHncw The article says a common sign of thrush is "the presence of creamy white, slightly raised lesions in your mouth - usually on your tongue or inner cheeks but also sometimes on the roof of your mouth, gums, tonsils, or back of your throat." The third page of the article also has a section on treatment options that you may wish to look through.

Thrush is caused by the candida fungus and can also occur in other parts of the body, which could explain the vaginal yeast infections you are experiencing. This is something that you should discuss further with your doctor.

Finally, here is a slideshow of top problems in your mouth that has some pictures of common tongue problems (thrush is on slide 2) that you may find helpful to look through and compare to your tongue: http://wb.md/2dp0gEu

I hope you'll check back in and let us know how you're doing soon!
